It is unclear how useful the stage-approach adopted by Chadwick is when attempting to grasp something of the subtelty of Cassian's doctrine of prayer. For example, in Conference Nine, 16 Cassian says it is impossible "for our spirit to attain those more exalted modes of prayer of which I have been speaking except by the step-by-step journey upward through ail those pleas we pour forth (p. 110)." This passage indicates a successive view of the phases of the spiritual life. However, in the preceding chapters Cassian discusses différent sources and types of prayer and to whom each is particularly well-suited. But then he says that a soul that has become rooted in a State of purity "takes on ail the forms of prayer at the same time. It flies from one to the other, like an uncontrollable grasping fire (9,15 [p. 110])". This, by contrast, would seem to indicate transcendence of a strictly phasic view of the life of prayer. This is something to keep in mind when reading contemplative authors, who often do not ascribe the chronological fixity to stages in the spiritual life that modems ascribe to stages in psychologi- cal development (e.g., the work of A. Maslow). So, for example, while Origen sees stages as successive, Gregory of Nyssa allows for an overlapping of stages (see A. Louth. The Origins of the Christian Mystical Tradition [Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1981], p. 82).

That Cassian should posit some sort of intrinsic connection between the soul aflame with love of God and the filial adoption implied in the term "Our Father" is interesting. It is evocative of a relatively common image in patristic literature for divinization: wood being burned until it gradually takes on the properties of fire. The doctrinal thèmes of synergy, divinization, adoption, cré- ation, and rédemption all Cluster here.

It is important to maintain the distinction between the experience of turmoil and not getting tangled in it. The contemplative is not exempt from the experience of inner turmoil (a term which necessarily covers a vast semantic field: from polit- ical power struggles to gossip at table to interior trials) and, in fact, is often more vulnerable to it. In his book, House of Wisdom (New York: Harper and Row, 1985), John S. Dunne expresses this through the metaphor of a storm: an impor- tant leg of the spiritual journey is moving through the storm into its eye and then Walking with this storm in order to remain in the still simplicity of its eye.
